title: Todd v. Joyner
description: In this case, the Court affirmed the decision of the Court of Appeals barring the introduction of evidence of payments from an insurance company to an expert and finding no error in the trial court's decision to allow the expert to read from medical records during his testimony.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Frances Irene
          Todd, Petitioner,
        v.
        Barbara C.
          Joyner, Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS 

Appeal from Georgetown County
Thomas A. Russo, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26722
  Heard June 9, 2009 - Re-filed November 2,
2009Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Gene
          M. Connell, Jr., of Kelaher, Connell & Connor, of Surfside Beach, for
          Petitioner.
        Linda
          Weeks Gangi, of Thompson and Henry, of Conway, for Respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE
  PLEICONES:Â  This case stems from an
  auto accident in which Petitioner Frances Irene Todd was injured.Â  A jury
  awarded Todd $37,191.11.Â  Petitioner appealed and the Court of Appeals
  affirmed.Â  Todd v. Joyner, Op. No.
  4315 (S.C. Ct. App. re-filed January 18, 2008) (2009 Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 46
  at 15).[1]Â 
  We granted certiorari and, finding no error, now affirm the Court of Appeals.
FACTS
A
  car driven by Joyner collided with a car in which Todd was a passenger.Â  Todd
  sustained injuries and sued for damages.Â  State Farm, Joynerâ€™s insurer, defended
  her at trial.Â  Joyner admitted negligence
  and the trial court directed a verdict on liability.Â  Consequently, the sole
  issue before the jury was the amount of damages owed Todd.Â  In disputing Toddâ€™s
  claimed damages, Joyner presented Dr. Richard J. Friedman as an expert in
  orthopedic surgery.Â  Because Dr. Friedman was unavailable during trial, his
  deposition testimony was read to the jury.Â  At the deposition, Todd questioned
  Dr. Friedman concerning his relationship with State Farm, but Friedman was
  unable to provide answers to most questions.Â  Dr. Friedman testified that he
  did not know the number of times he testified for other lawyers in defense
  cases or how many depositions he testified in per year.Â  He explained that he
  does not keep records and routinely throws out invoices relating to past expert
  testimony once his bill is paid.Â  Moreover, when asked what percentage of his
  practice was comprised of expert testimony, Dr. Friedman answered â€œvery smallâ€
  and outlined a typical busy work week which left â€œnot much time . . . for
  anything else.â€
Following the deposition,
  Todd subpoenaed payment records from State Farm for regarding Dr. Friedmanâ€™s
  expert consultation in any case for the past three years.Â  The records supplied
  showed that Friedman was paid between $50,000 and $60,000 for work on eighteen
  different claim numbers during calendar years 2003-2005.Â  Todd attempted to
  introduce the payment records at trial as evidence of bias, but the trial judge
  refused, citing Rule 403 of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure
  (SCRCP).
In
  his testimony, Dr. Friedman opined that Todd suffered no permanent impairment
  from the auto accident and that any treatment she received more than roughly
  four months after the accident was not reasonable and necessary or proximately
  caused by the accident.Â  Dr. Friedman was the only expert whose testimony was
  offered at trial.Â  At the conclusion of the trial, the jury found for Todd in
  the amount of $37,191.11, the amount of medical bills presented at the trial.Â 
  Todd moved for additur and filed a motion for a new trial, both of which
  were denied.
Todd
  contested a number of evidentiary rulings by the trial court as well as the
  trial courtâ€™s refusal to grant her motion for additur.Â  The Court of
  Appeals affirmed the trial courtâ€™s rulings on all points.Â  Todd, 376
  S.C. 144, 654 S.E.2d 862.Â  We granted certiorari.Â  
ISSUES

  
    I. 
    Did the Court of Appeals err in
  affirming the trial court’s decision to bar the introduction of evidence of payments made by State
    Farm to the expert?
    
  
  
    II. 
    Did the Court of Appeals err in
  affirming the trial court’s decision allowing Joyner’s expert to read from
  Todd’s medical records during his testimony? 
  

DISCUSSION
I. Yoho v. Thompson
On certiorari,
  Todd argues that the Court of Appeals erred in affirming the trial courtâ€™s
  refusal to allow introduction of the payment records because the records were
  properly admissible to show bias under Yoho v. Thompson, 345 S.C. 361,
  548 S.E.2d 584 (2001).Â  We disagree.
Prior
  to 1995, the long-standing rule in South Carolina was that, in an action for
  damages, a defendantâ€™s insurance coverage should not be revealed to the jury.Â  Yoho,
  345 S.C. at 365, 548 S.E.2d at 585.Â  Rule 411 of the South Carolina Rules of
  Evidence (SCRE) altered the bar on evidence of insurance and provides:

  Evidence that a person was or was not insured against
    liability is not admissible upon the issue of whether the person acted
    negligently or otherwise wrongfully.Â  This rule does not require the exclusion
    of evidence of insurance against liability when offered for another purpose,
    such as proof of agency, ownership, or control, or bias or prejudice of a
    witness.

Rule 411, SCRE (2008).
In Yoho,
  we adopted a framework for analysis in considering whether or not to admit
  evidence of insurance.Â  We held that if Rule 411 does not require the exclusion
  of evidence of insurance, the court should then proceed to perform Rule 403
  analysis and consider whether the probative value of the evidence is
  substantially outweighed by the prejudicial effect and potential for confusing
  the jury.Â  Yoho, 345 S.C. at 365, 548 S.E.2d at 586.Â  As liability was
  admitted in this case, Rule 411 is not implicated and the question whether the
  records are admissible turns on Rule 403.
In
  considering whether an expertâ€™s connection to a defendantâ€™s insurer is
  sufficiently probative to outweigh the prejudice to the defendant resulting
  from the juryâ€™s knowledge that the defendant carries liability insurance, this
  Court adopted the â€œsubstantial connectionâ€ analysis employed in a majority of
  jurisdictions.Â  Id. at 366, 548 S.E.2d at 586.Â  Applying the
  â€œsubstantial connectionâ€ test, the Yoho Court noted (1) that the expert
  was not merely paid an expert fee in the case but instead maintained an
  employment relationship with the insurance company and other insurance
  companies; (2) the expert consulted for the insurance company and gave lectures
  to its agents and adjusters; (3) 10-20% of the expertâ€™s practice consisted of
  reviewing records for insurance companies; and (4) the expertâ€™s yearly salary
  was based in part on his insurance consulting work.Â  Id.Â  Based on these
  facts, the Yoho Court found that the expert had a substantial connection
  to the insurance company and therefore, the trial court erred in barring
  admission of evidence of insurance.Â  Id.
Todd
  showed, through payment records and the testimony of Potts, that Dr. Friedman
  earned approximately $50,000 from State Farm during calendar years 2003-2005
  based on work on eighteen claims, but presented no evidence as to Dr.
  Friedmanâ€™s total earnings during that period.Â  Moreover, unlike Yoho,
  the evidence appears to show that Dr. Friedman was paid an expert fee rather
  than having an employment relationship with State Farm.Â  In short, the evidence
  presented by Todd does not show as strong a connection between the expert and
  the insurance company as in Yoho and we cannot conclude that the Court
  of Appeals erred in affirming the trial court. 
II. Medical Records
Todd
  contends that the Court of Appeals erred in upholding the trial courtâ€™s
  decision allowing Dr. Friedman to read from Toddâ€™s medical records at trial.Â 
  We disagree.
During
  the deposition, which was read to the jury at trial, Dr. Friedman was asked to
  comment on the reasonableness of Toddâ€™s medical treatment and whether injuries
  Todd claimed resulted from the car accident actually existed before that time.Â 
  Dr. Friedman based his opinions, in part, on a review of Toddâ€™s medical records
  and, in explaining his opinions, Dr. Friedman referenced Toddâ€™s medical records
  a number of times and occasionally read from the records.Â  Since Dr. Friedmanâ€™s
  testimony centered on the idea that injuries Todd claimed resulted from the
  wreck actually existed prior to the accident, most of the portions of the
  records read by Dr. Friedman referred to Toddâ€™s statements or complaints to her
  doctors.[2]
At
  trial, Todd objected to Dr. Friedmanâ€™s testimony as to medical records as
  hearsay.Â  We find no error.Â  We find that the records introduced through Dr.
  Friedmanâ€™s testimony referring to complaints or statements Todd made to her
  physicians are not barred by the hearsay rule.Â  Rule 803, SCRE provides as
  follows:

  The following are not excluded by the hearsay rule,
    even though the declarant is available as a witness:
  . . . 
  (4) Statements for Purposes of Medical Diagnosis or
    Treatment.Â  Statements made for purposes of medical diagnosis or treatment and
    describing medical history, or past or present symptoms, pain, or sensations,
    or the inception or general character of the cause or external source thereof
    insofar as reasonably pertinent to diagnosis or treatment; provided, however,
    that the admissibility of statements made after commencement of the litigation
    is left to the courtâ€™s discretion.

Rule 803(4), SCRE (2008).Â 
  The medical history referenced by Dr. Friedman falls within the ambit of Rule
  803(4) and therefore, does not run afoul of the hearsay rule.Â  The Court of
  Appeals, therefore, did not err in affirming the trial courtâ€™s decision to
  allow the testimony.
CONCLUSION
We find that the
  Court of Appeals did not err in affirming the trial courtâ€™s finding that Todd
  did not show a â€œsubstantial connectionâ€ between State Farm and Dr. Friedman to
  require admission of evidence of insurance.Â  We further find no error in the
  decision to allow Dr. Friedman to refer to Toddâ€™s medical records, and
  therefore affirm on this ground.Â  We affirm all remaining issues under Rule
  220(c).
AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J.,
  WALLER, J., and Acting Justice E. C. Burnett, III, concur.Â  BEATTY, J.,
  dissenting in a separate opinion.

JUSTICE BEATTY:Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  Dr. Friedman was employed by State Farm on
  eighteen different occasions over a three year period immediately prior to
  trial.Â  This employment relationship clearly constitutes a substantial
  connection between State Farm and Dr. Friedman.Â  Evidence of this substantial
  connection should have been admitted to show possible bias on Dr. Friedmanâ€™s
  part.Â  See Yoho v. Thompson, 345 S.C. 361, 548 S.E.2d 584 (2001)
  (holding evidence of a defense expertâ€™s medical consulting work for an
  insurance carrier was admissible, even though the evidence contained a
  reference to insurance, because considerable latitude is allowed during
  cross-examination to test a witnessâ€™s bias, prejudice, or credibility).
The probative value of this evidence far outweighed
  its prejudicial effect.Â  See id. at 366, 548 S.E.2d at 586
  (stating that a substantial connection between an expert and a defendantâ€™s
  insurer is sufficiently probative on the issue of bias so as to outweigh the
  prejudice to the defendant resulting from the fact that the jury knows the
  defendant carries liability insurance).Â  Considering the fact that liability
  insurance has been required in South Carolina for decades, see S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§Â§ 56-10-10, -20, -220 (2006), it is highly probable that every juror
  already knew that insurance was available.Â  The only unknown was the name of
  the carrier.Â  Therefore, it is probable that there was no prejudicial effect to
  be concerned with.
Connecting Dr. Friedman to the insurance carrier was
  highly probative on the issue of his bias in favor of the insurance carrier,
  State Farm, and Joyner.Â  In my view there was very little, if any, unfair
  prejudice to Joyner.
I concur in the remaining issues.Â  


[1] The Court of Appeals filed the original opinion in this matter on November 27,
  2007.Â  The Court of Appeals denied the petition for rehearing but withdrew the
  original opinion and substituted the above-referenced opinion, which makes only
  minor changes to the original version.Â  Apparently, the new opinion was never
  submitted for publication.Â  We now revise the citation to reference the
  re-filed opinion.
[2] For example, Dr. Friedman testified that Todd â€œdid complain of headaches to her
  doctor on March 19th, 1998.â€

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        In the Matter of George A.
          Harper, Respondent.
      
    
  


Opinion No.Â  26737
Submitted October 13, 2009 - Filed November 4, 2009Â  

DEFINITE SUSPENSION


  
    
      
        Lesley M.
          Coggiola, Disciplinary Counsel, and C. Tex Davis, Jr., Senior Assistant
          Disciplinary Counsel, both of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary Counsel. 
        John S.
          Simmons, of Simmons Law Firm, of Columbia, for respondent.Â Â Â  
      
    
  


PER
  CURIAM:Â Â  In this attorney disciplinary
  matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered
  into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent (Agreement) pursuant to Rule 21,
  RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  In the Agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents
  to the issuance of a public reprimand or a definite suspension not exceed
  ninety (90) days.Â  See Rule 7(b), RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  Respondent requests that, if the Court imposes a
  suspension, that the suspension be made retroactive to March 31, 2009, the date
  of his interim suspension.Â  In the Matter of Harper, 382 S.C. 162, 675
  S.E.2d 721 (2009).Â  We accept the Agreement and definitely suspend respondent
  from the practice of law in this state for a ninety (90) day period,
  retroactive to the date of his interim suspension.Â  The facts, as set forth in
  the Agreement, are as follows.Â  
FACTS
Respondent pled guilty to
  one count of willful failure to file a state income tax return and failure to
  pay taxes in violation of South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 12-54-44(B)(3) (2000) and
  was sentenced accordingly.Â  Â Respondent represents he has paid the taxes owed
  and the costs of the prosecution.Â  
LAW
Respondent
  admits that by his misconduct he has violated the following provisions of the
  Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 8.4(a) (lawyer shall not violate Rules of
    Professional Conduct) and Rule 8.4(b) (lawyer shall not commit a criminal act
    that reflects adversely on the lawyerâ€™s honesty, trustworthiness, or fitness as
    a lawyer in other respects). Â In addition, respondent admits
  his misconduct constitutes a violation of Rule 7, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR,
  specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be a ground for discipline for a lawyer to
  violate the Rules of Professional Conduct or any other rules of this
  jurisdiction regarding professional conduct of lawyers), Rule 7(a)(4) (it shall
  be a ground for discipline for a lawyer to be convicted of a crime of moral
  turpitude or a serious crime), and Rule 7(a)(5) (it shall be a ground for
  discipline for a lawyer to engage in conduct tending to pollute the
  administration of justice or to bring the courts or the legal profession into
  disrepute or conduct demonstrating an unfitness to practice law).Â  Â Â 
CONCLUSION
We accept the Agreement for Discipline by
  Consent and definitely suspend respondent from the practice of law for a ninety
  (90) day period.Â  We grant respondentâ€™s request that the suspension be made
  retroactive to the date of his interim suspension.Â  Within fifteen days of the
  date of this opinion, respondent shall file an affidavit with the Clerk of
  Court showing that he has complied with Rule 30, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.
DEFINITE SUSPENSION.
WALLER, ACTING CHIEF JUSTICE,
  PLEICONES, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur. TOAL, C.J., not participating.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Governor Mark
      Sanford, Petitioner,
				v.
				South Carolina State Ethics Commission and Herbert R. Hayden, 
				Jr., in his official capacity as Executive Director of the State 
				Ethics Commission, Respondents,
				The Honorable Robert W. Harrell, Jr., Speaker of the South 
				Carolina House of Representatives, Intervenor.
				and
				The Honorable Robert W.
      Harrell, Jr., Speaker of the South Carolina House of Representatives, Petitioner,
				v.
				South Carolina State
      Ethics Commission and Herbert R. Hayden, Jr., in his official capacity as
      Executive Director of the State Ethics Commission, Respondents,
				Governor Mark
          Sanford, Intervenor.
			
		
	


ORIGINAL JURISDICTION

Opinion No.Â  26741
Heard October 19, 2009 - Filed November 5,
  2009Â  
RELIEF DENIED


	
		
			
				Karl
  S. Bowers, Jr., Kevin A. Hall, and M. Todd Carroll, all of Columbia, for Petitioner
  and Intervenor Governor Mark
  Sanford.
				Charles
  F. Reid, Bradley S. Wright, Bonnie B. Goldsmith and Patrick G. Dennis, all of
  Columbia, for Petitioner and Intervenor Speaker Robert W. Harrell, Jr.
				Cathy
  L. Hazelwood, of Columbia, for Respondents South Carolina State Ethics
  Commission and Herbert R.
  Hayden, Jr., in his official capacity as Executive Director of the State Ethics
  Commission.
			
		
	


JUSTICE WALLER:Â  These matters involve the confidentiality of an ethics
  investigation involving Governor Mark Sanford which is currently pending before
  the South Carolina State Ethics Commission (Commission).Â  
PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On September 30, 2009, Governor Sanford petitioned this Court for
  a writ of mandamus directing the Commission to comply with the statute and
  regulations regarding confidentiality of Commission proceedings.Â  More
  specifically, the Governor requested that the Commission not be permitted to
  publicly disseminate any investigatory reports or other information about this
  investigation.Â  The Commission filed a return in opposition to the Governorâ€™s
  petition for a writ of mandamus.Â  
Robert
  W. Harrell, Jr., Speaker of the South Carolina House of Representatives, then filed
  a motion to intervene in the Governorâ€™s action.Â  We granted that motion, and
  the Speaker filed a return in opposition to the Governorâ€™s petition.Â  In
  addition, Speaker Harrell filed his own petition for a writ of mandamus in the
  Courtâ€™s original jurisdiction.Â  The Speaker asked the Court to direct the
  Commission to issue â€œits investigation materials and information to the House
  of Representativesâ€ because
  the House is â€œthe sole prosecuting authority for purposes of impeachment.â€ Â The Commission filed a return in
  opposition to the Speakerâ€™s petition.Â  The Governor sought to intervene in the
  Speakerâ€™s action; we granted that request.
Because of the exigencies related to the case, we agreed to
  entertain this matter in the Courtâ€™s original jurisdiction, on an expedited
  basis, and heard oral arguments of the parties on October 19, 2009.Â  On October
  21, 2009, we issued an order requesting additional materials and briefs from
  the parties on the issue of waiver.Â  With that briefing now complete, the
  matter is ripe for our decision.
FACTS
By letter dated August 18, 2009, Governor Sanford was informed by
  Herbert R. Hayden, Jr., Executive Director of the Commission, that the
  Commission had determined an ethics complaint against the Governor set forth â€œsufficient
  factsâ€ to warrant an investigation.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  8-13-320(10)(c) (Supp. 2008).Â  The Governor was informed that: (1) he would be
  contacted by an investigator concerning any statements he desired to make; and
  (2) he could provide a written response to the complaint and include any
  documentation he would like for the Commission to consider.

	Significantly,
  this letter also advised the Governor of the following:
	
		In accordance with [S.C. Code Ann.] Section 8-13-320(9) and (10), all
  complaints, investigations, inquires [sic], hearings, and accompanying
  documents are confidential unless the respondent waives the right to
    confidentiality in writing to the Commission, or the Commission issues a
  public dispositionâ€¦.Â  
	

(Emphasis added).
By
  letter to Hayden dated August 24, 2009, counsel for the Governor stated
  it was his understanding that if the Governor waived his right to
  confidentiality the following would apply:

	
		
			1. 
			The only information
  that will be made public during the pendency of this matter is the fact that an
  investigation is being conducted and the Complaint Form itself;
 
		
		
			2.   
			The investigation and the results thereof, 
			including any statements or documents, will remain confidential and 
			will not be made public at any time, either during or after the 
			conclusion of this matter;
 
		
		
			3.  
			If a hearing is held in this matter, such hearing 
			will be held in executive session unless Governor Sanford requests 
			an open hearing; and
 
		
		
			4. 
			Any action taken by the Commission will be made 
			public upon final disposition.
		
	

 (Emphasis in
  original).Â  Counsel for the Governor further represented that his understanding
  was based on information Hayden had given him during their recent discussions
  regarding the impact of a potential waiver by the Governor.
Hayden responded to counselâ€™s letter with his own letter dated
  August 27, 2009, which stated: 

	If Governor Sanford waives his right to confidentiality, the
  following will apply:
	
		
			1. 
			The only
  information that will be made public during the pendency of this matter is the
  fact that an investigation is being conducted and the Complaint Form itself;
 
		
		
			2. 
			 The investigative
  report, including any statements or documents, will not become part of the
  public record; however, any testimony given, documents entered into evidence at
  an administrative hearing, and the Commissionâ€™s findings will become a part of
  the formal record along with the Commissionâ€™s Decision and Order, and will be
  public;
 
		
		
			3. 
			If a hearing is held in this matter, such hearing 
			will be held in executive session unless Governor Sanford requests 
			an open hearing; and
 
		
		
			4.  
			Any action taken by the Commission will be made 
			public upon final disposition.
		
	

(Emphasis
  added).Â  Hayden also stated that the only item â€œaffected by a waiver of
  confidentiality is Item 1. Â Items 2, 3 and 4 are required by either statute
    or regulation and will apply regardless of a waiver.â€Â  (Emphasis added).
The
  following day, August 28, 2009, the Governor himself (i.e., not counsel
  for the Governor) sent a signed letter to Hayden setting forth his record of â€œgoing
  the extra mile in fighting for transparency in our state government.â€Â  The
  Governorâ€™s August 28th letter further stated as follows:Â  

	In an effort to once again go the extra mile, I would like to
  waive my right to confidentiality in your upcoming ethics probe.Â  I believe that what 
	the whole of our
    travel records will show is that this administration has worked very hard
  to be a good steward of taxpayer resources.
	Itâ€™s also my hope that my decision to take the unilateral step
  of waiving confidentiality will serve to encourage both the public to
  invite, and legislators to lead, in changing the current system.Â  In this system all constitutional
  officers, and every state employee, is held to one standard - while the General
  Assembly lives under a completely different standard without transparency.Â  I
  strongly believe this needs to change, and again do hope this is one of the
  byproducts of what takes place this fall.[1]

(Emphasis added.)

In
  his petition for a writ of mandamus, Governor Sanford maintains he actually
  intended his August 28th letter to be a â€œlimitedâ€ waiver of
  confidentiality and not the unconditional waiver conveyed by the letterâ€™s clear
  terms.
The Governorâ€™s counsel met with Hayden on September 8, 2009.
  Hayden advised counsel that the Commission intended to publicly distribute its
  preliminary investigative report to the House of Representatives.
On
  September 14, 2009, the Governor filed a Motion to Enjoin Dissemination of
  Investigative Report with the Commission.[2]Â 
  By letter dated September 15, 2009, Cathy Hazelwood, counsel for the
  Commission, advised the Governorâ€™s counsel that the motion was premature
  because the investigation into this matter is â€œongoing and no report has been
  begun, let alone completed.â€Â  She explained the Governor would receive the
  report â€œwhen the Commission receives the report,â€ and at that time, there would
  be an opportunity â€œto argue any and all motions related to this matter.â€
Regarding
  Speaker Harrellâ€™s petition for a writ of mandamus, he argues
  that pursuant to Article XV,
  Section 1 of the South Carolina Constitution, the House has the sole power of
  impeachment.[3]Â 
  Therefore, because the House of Representatives is the
  prosecutorial authority for purposes of impeachment, the Speaker contends this Court should order the Commission to release its
  investigation materials to the House.Â  Â Â 
ISSUES

	
		
			1.
			Has either the Governor or the Speaker met the 
			requirements for the issuance of a writ of mandamus?
 
		
		
			2.
			Does the Governorâ€™s August 28th letter constitute a complete waiver of confidentiality under S.C. Code Ann. 
			
			Â§
  8-13-320(10)(g)?
		
	

DISCUSSION
1.Â  Writ of Mandamus
This
  Court has the power to issue writs or orders of injunction or mandamus.Â  S.C.
  Const. Art. V, Â§ 5; S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-3-310 (1976).Â  The writ of mandamus is â€œthe highest
  judicial writ known to the law.â€ Â Willimon
    v. City of Greenville, 243 S.C. 82, 86, 132 S.E.2d 169, 170 (1963); accord Edwards v. State, 383 S.C. 82, 678
  S.E. 2d 412 (2009); City of Rock Hill v. Thompson, 349 S.C. 197, 563
  S.E.2d 101 (2002); Ex parte
    Littlefield, 343 S.C. 212, 540 S.E.2d
  81 (2000). Â The â€œprincipal functionâ€ of
  mandamus â€œis to command and execute, and not to inquire and adjudicate;
  therefore, it is not the purpose
  of the writ to establish a legal right, but to enforce one which has already
  been established.â€Â  Willimon, 132 S.E.2d at 171; see also Porter
    v. Jedziniak, 334 S.C. 16, 18, 512 S.E.2d 497, 497 (1999) (â€œThe primary
  purpose of a writ of mandamus is to enforce an established right and to enforce
  a corresponding imperative duty created or imposed by law.â€); 


    Redmond v. Lexington County Sch.
      Dist. No. 4, 314 S.C. 431, 445 S.E.2d
  441 (1994) (a writ of mandamus is not appropriate for a discretionary authority).
To
  obtain a writ of mandamus requiring the performance of an act, the petitioner
  must show: Â (1) a duty to perform the act; (2) the ministerial nature of the
  act; (3) the petitionerâ€™s specific legal right for which discharge of the duty
  is necessary; and (4) a lack of any other legal remedy.Â  E.g., Wilson
    v. Preston, 378 S.C. 348, 662 S.E.2d 580 (2008); Porter v. Jedziniak, supra; Willimon, supra.Â  Mandamus is based on the theory
  that an officer charged with a purely ministerial duty can be compelled to
  perform that duty in case of refusal.Â  Wilson v. Preston, supra.
The confidentiality provision of the Ethics Act is found in S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 8-13-320(10)(g), which states as follows:

	All investigations, inquiries, hearings, and accompanying
  documents must remain confidential until final disposition of a matter unless
  the respondent waives the right to confidentiality.Â  The willful release of confidential
  information is a misdemeanor, and any person releasing such confidential
  information, upon conviction, must be fined not more than one thousand dollars
  or imprisoned not more than one year.

(Emphasis
  added).Â  
We find
  there is no ministerial act to be performed under this provision, and
  consequently no duty to perform the act.Â  Â Â Moreover, the Governor has other
  legal remedies available.Â  As noted, the Governor has a motion for an
  injunction pending before the Commission in which he seeks the same relief he
  is seeking from this Court.Â  The Commission has indicated it will not
  disseminate the investigative summary or preliminary report in this matter
  until the Governorâ€™s motion has been heard and acted upon by the Commission
  and, if the Commissionâ€™s decision is adverse to the Governor, until he has had
  an opportunity to seek review of that decision.Â  For these reasons, a writ of
  mandamus is simply not available to the Governor under these circumstances and
  his petition is therefore denied.
Likewise,
  there is no ministerial act under the statute requiring the Commissionâ€™s investigation
  materials to be provided to the House of Representatives.Â  While the Ethics Act
  clearly indicates the statute â€œdoes not limit the power of either chamber of
  the General Assembly to impeach a public official,â€ S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  8-13-320(n), it is nonetheless indisputable that there is no â€œimperative duty created or imposed byâ€ the Ethics Act
  which compels the Commission to release its investigation materials to the
  House.Â  Porter v. Jedziniak, 334 S.C. at 18, 512 S.E.2d at 497.[4]Â  
Furthermore,
  we note the House has a number of alternative avenues available for obtaining
  the information it seeks, none of which have been pursued.Â  See, e.g.,
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 2-69-10 (2005); S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  30-4-10 et seq. (2007 & Supp. 2008).Â  Additionally, as
  the parties conceded at oral argument in this matter, the pending ethics
  investigation is wholly unrelated to any potential impeachment.Â  The House of
  Representatives may proceed (or not proceed) with impeachment at its own
  choosing, irrespective of any finding by the Commission, or any other
  investigation of the Governor.
Accordingly, like the Governor, the Speaker has failed to
  establish the necessary requirements for issuing a writ of mandamus; therefore,
  we deny the Speakerâ€™s petition as well.

2. Waiver
Although a writ of mandamus is unavailable to the Governor, we are
  cognizant of the Governorâ€™s pending motion filed with the Commission for an injunction based on the same legal grounds as are asserted to this Court in his petition
  for a writ of mandamus.Â  Because it is â€œthe substance of the requested relief that mattersâ€ and not
  the form in which the petition for relief is framed, we may construe the
  Governorâ€™s request as one for injunctive relief if that is substantively what
  he is requesting.[5]Â  Historic Charleston Holdings, LLC v. Mallon,
  381 S.C. 417, 437, 673 S.E.2d 448, 458 (2009); accord Richland County v. Kaiser, 351 S.C. 89, 567
  S.E.2d 260 (Ct. App. 2002) (where the Court of
  Appeals treated a denial of a petition for a writ of mandamus as a denial of
  injunctive relief).
Generally
  speaking, an injunction should be granted only where some irreparable injury is
  threatened for which the parties have no adequate remedy at law.Â  Greenwood
    County v. Shay, 202 S.C. 16, 23 S.E.2d 825 (1943).Â  The Governor contends that if the Commission is allowed to publicly disclose information about the investigation, â€œthe
  integrity of the entire processâ€ would be destroyed.Â  Thus, he has requested
  that we prevent the Commission from publicly distributing any
  investigatory reports or other information about the investigation.Â  Given the
  arguments raised by the Governor, we find
  the requested relief is akin to a prohibitory injunction.[6] Â Accordingly, we will also construe the petition as one asking for injunctive
  relief. Â 
The
  Governorâ€™s argument is based upon the confidentiality provision of the Ethics
  Act and the accompanying regulations.Â  See Â§ 8-13-320(10)(g); S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 52-718 (Supp. 2008).Â  As
  outlined above, the Ethics Act clearly provides a right of confidentiality; just
  as clearly, however, the statute allows this right to be waived by the
  respondent under investigation. Â Â§ 8-13-320(10)(g); S.C.
  Code Ann. Regs. 52-718(B) (Supp. 2008) (the
  respondent â€œmay waive the confidentiality of the proceeding in writing filed
  with the Commissionâ€).
The dispositive issue therefore becomes:Â  Did the Governorâ€™s
  August 28th letter waive his right to confidentiality?
A waiver is a voluntary and intentional abandonment or
  relinquishment of a known right. Â E.g., Eason v. Eason, 384 S.C. 473,
  682 S.E.2d 804 (2009).Â  Waiver requires a party to have known of a right and
  known that right was being abandoned.Â  Id.Â  The determination of whether oneâ€™s actions constitute
  waiver is a question of fact.Â  Laser Supply and Servs., Inc. v. Orchard Park
    Assocs., 382 S.C. 326, 676 S.E.2d 139 (Ct. App. 2009). Â Because the instant case has been brought in the Courtâ€™s
  original jurisdiction, it is within the province of this Court to make findings
  of fact and conclusions of law regarding the issues before us.Â  See Johnson
    v. Catoe, 345 S.C. 389, 548 S.E.2d 587 (2001); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-3-340
  (1976).Â  
Initially,
  we find the Governor knew of his right to confidentiality, as it was clearly
  set forth and correctly stated in the complaint and the initial letter from the
  Commission, which was sent directly to Governor Sanford and not to his
  counsel.Â  The Governor asserts, however, that his
  August 28th letter effected a â€œlimitedâ€ waiver of confidentiality,
  and his expectation was that only the existence of an investigation and the contents of the Complaint would be
  made publicly available.
We disagree.Â  The intent of the August 28th letter -
  which Governor Sanford himself signed and was written on the Governorâ€™s
  letterhead - is clear from the letterâ€™s plain language:

	In an effort to once again go the extra mile, I would like to
  waive my right to confidentiality in your upcoming ethics probe.

Moreover, the
  Governor characterized this waiver as a â€œunilateral step.â€Â  Governor Sanfordâ€™s
  August 28th letter did not limit the waiver in any way, shape or
  form.Â  It did not reference the very specifically delineated restrictions that had
  been outlined by Hayden to the Governorâ€™s counsel. Â Indeed, the Governor
  specifically stated this is â€œmy decision.â€ Â The additional language the Governor used in the letter, regarding
  â€œfighting for transparency,â€ disclosure, as well as his reference to travel
  records - which would not have been disclosed under the partial waiver that had
  been discussed between the Governorâ€™s counsel and Hayden - indicates
  his intent was to waive confidentiality without limitation and without
  reliance upon the communications between his counsel and Hayden.[7]
Thus, the only reasonable interpretation of Governor Sanfordâ€™s
  August 28th letter is that it was an intentional relinquishment of
  the right to confidentiality, and therefore a valid - and complete - waiver.Â  Eason, supra.
Governor Sanford also maintains that even when confidentiality is
  waived pursuant to section 8-13-320(10)(g), the waiver is limited by the regulations applicable to confidentiality.Â  We
  disagree.
Section 8-13-320(10)(g) states that â€œ[a]ll
  investigations, inquiries, hearings, and accompanying documents must remain
  confidential until final disposition of a matter unless the respondent waives
  the right to confidentiality.â€ 
Regulation
  52-718 governs the confidentiality of the Commissionâ€™s ethics proceedings.Â 
  Subsection 52-718(F) provides as follows:

	After
  the final disposition of a matter where a violation is found, the Commission
  shall prepare a public record which shall consist of the pleadings and record
  of the hearing.Â  The Commissionâ€™s internal and investigatory papers including
  work product shall not be made part of the public record.


Based on regulation
  52-718(F), the Governor argues the Commissionâ€™s â€œpreliminary reports and other
  working papers remain confidentialâ€ even if the respondent has waived his right
  to confidentiality under section 8-13-320(10)(g).Â  We
  disagree.
Although
  regulations authorized by the Legislature generally have the force of law, a
  regulation may not alter or add to the terms of a statute.Â  Gaffney Ledger
    v. S.C. Ethics Commâ€™n, 360 S.C. 107, 600 S.E.2d 540 (2004); Goodman
      v. City of Columbia, 318 S.C. 488, 458 S.E.2d 531 (1995); Banks v.
        Batesburg Hauling Co., 202 S.C. 273, 24 S.E.2d 496 (1943); see also Society of Profâ€™l Journalists v. Sexton, 283 S.C. 563, 567, 324 S.E.2d
  313, 315 (1984) (â€œAlthough a regulation has the force of law, it must fall
  when it alters or adds to a statute.â€).
Initially, we find
  Regulation 52-718(F) is not even implicated by this case because it addresses
  what would become the public record after the final disposition of a
    matter where a violation is found.Â  In contrast, the Governor is primarily
  concerned with the release of investigatory materials during the ongoing
  investigation stage because - according to the Governor - he will not get a
  chance to present â€œhis side of the storyâ€ until probable cause is found and a
  hearing is held.[8]Â 
  Regardless, because we find Governor Sanford has waived his right to
  confidentiality, the import of Regulation 52-718(F) is irrelevant.Â  However, to the extent Regulation
  52-718(F) may be construed to limit the materials covered by a respondentâ€™s waiver
  which is allowed by
  section 8-13-320(10)(g), it is invalid.Â  Gaffney
    Ledger v. S.C. Ethics Commâ€™n, supra (a regulation may not alter the terms of a statute); Goodman
      v. City of Columbia, supra (same).Â  
Although
  we conclude the Governorâ€™s August 28th letter constituted a complete
  waiver of his right to confidentiality under section 8-13-320(10)(g), we hasten to add that the Governorâ€™s waiver does not
  reach the Commissionâ€™s work product.Â  To
  permit a respondentâ€™s waiver to include the Commissionâ€™s work product and
  internal investigative process would chill the Commissionâ€™s ability to
  thoroughly investigate a complaint.Â  The policy reasons for maintaining the
  confidentiality of the Commissionâ€™s work product (especially during the
  investigative process) are self-evident and compelling.Â  Governor
  Sanfordâ€™s waiver here, of course, reaches all documentation to which he is entitled.[9]Â  Otherwise, we respect the Commissionâ€™s authority in
  the first instance to determine what matters and documentation are subject to
  the Governorâ€™s waiver, which the
  Commission can make in ruling on the Governorâ€™s pending motion for an
  injunction.Â  See Brown v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 354 S.C. 436, 440, 581
  S.E.2d 836, 838 (2003) (â€œ[T]he Court generally gives
  deference to an administrative agencyâ€™s interpretation of an applicable statute
  or its own regulation.â€).Â  
Accordingly, to the extent the Governorâ€™s petition seeks
  injunctive relief, the petition is denied. 
CONCLUSION
For the
  reasons discussed above, the relief requested by both the Governor and the
  Speaker is 
DENIED.
TOAL, C.J., BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur. PLEICONES, J., concurring in a
  separate opinion.

JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I agree with the majority that both petitions
  should be denied for the reasons stated.Â  
      

I
  respectfully differ, however, with the finding of fact which concludes that the
  only reasonable interpretation of the Governorâ€™s letter of August 28, 2009, is
  that it constitutes a complete waiver of confidentiality under S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  8-13-320(10)(g).Â  Though the letter of August 28 certainly constitutes a
  waiver, I am not persuaded that the evidence before us demonstrates that the
  Governor knew that he was waiving all confidentiality.Â  See Eason
    v. Eason, 384 S.C. 473, 682 S.E.2d 804 (2009) (waiver
  requires a party to have known of a right and known he was abandoning that
  right); Historic Charleston Holdings, LLC v. Mallon, 381 S.C.
  417, 433, 673 S.E.2d 448, 456 (2009) (waiver is the voluntary and intentional
  abandonment or relinquishment of a known right by a party that knew of its
  rights, or of all the material facts upon which they depend).Â  To the contrary,
  I conclude that the letter of August 28, 2009, though grandiose and
  poorly-articulated, is clearly the end-product of negotiations between the
  Governorâ€™s counsel and the executive director of the Ethics Commission.Â  In
  making this finding, I have considered Mr. Haydenâ€™s letters of August 18 and
  27, 2009; the Governorâ€™s counselâ€™s letter of August 24, 2009; the Governorâ€™s
  affidavit filed herein; and, of course, the Governorâ€™s letter of August 28,
  2009.Â  
      

I
  would have allowed the Ethics Commission to determine in the first instance the
  meaning and scope of the August 28, 2009, letter in the proceeding referenced
  by the majority.Â  That avenue is now foreclosed.Â  To the extent that the
  majority may suggest that a waiver submitted pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 8-13-320(10)(g)
  cannot be limited, I would find that the Governorâ€™s attempt at doing that which
  cannot be done, constitutes a nullity.


[1] Moreover, we note the Governor also issued a press release on August 28th which stated in relevant part:

	In the continued spirit of a fair
  and transparent process, I am today announcing that Iâ€™ll be waiving
  confidentiality as the Ethics Commission studies some of the allegations made
  in the press and by political detractors.Â  Our administration has nothing to
  hide.Â  We would welcome the public to scrutinize our record, just as the Ethics
  Commission will do.

See http://www.scgovernor.com/news/releases/8-28-2009.htm.
[2] The motion for an injunction requested that the Commission enjoin itself,
  including all commissioners and staff members, from disseminating any
  investigative reports, recommendations, pre-hearing reports, or any other
  written or oral materials or information regarding this matter that may be
  created by any person associated with the Commission.Â  The motion is nearly
  identical to the petition for a writ of mandamus filed in this Court.
[3] Article XV, Section 1 provides as follows:

	The House of Representatives alone
  shall have the power of impeachment in cases of serious crimes or serious
  misconduct in office by officials elected on a statewide basis, state judges,
  and such other state officers as may be designated by law.Â  The affirmative
  vote of two-thirds of all members elected shall be required for an
  impeachment.Â  Any officer impeached shall thereby be suspended from office
  until judgment in the case shall have been pronounced, and the office shall be
  filled during the trial in such manner as may be provided by law.

[4] We note that with regard to turning over evidence to the Attorney General, the
  Ethics Act provides it is within the â€œdiscretionâ€ of the Commission whether to
  do so.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 8-13-320(h).Â  Discretionary authority, however, is
  insufficient for mandamus.Â  See Redmond v. Lexington County Sch.
    Dist. No. 4, 314 S.C. at 438, 445 S.E.2d at 445 (a writ of mandamus is inappropriate for a discretionary authority).Â  To the extent the Speaker argues S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 52-718(C)
  (Supp. 2008) - which permits the Commission to release information â€œto another
  prosecuting authorityâ€ - creates an imperative duty appropriate for
  mandamus, we disagree.
[5] As previously discussed, this Court has the power to issue a writ or order of injunction.Â 
  S.C. Const. Art. V, Â§ 5; S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-3-310.
[6] A prohibitory injunction is defined as an injunction â€œthat forbids or restrains
  an act.â€Â  Blacks Law DictionaryÂ Â  855 (9th ed. 2009).
[7] Governor Sanfordâ€™s press release of the same day confirms this reading.Â  See fn.1, supra.
[8] We note the plain language of the statute refutes the
  Governorâ€™s contention.Â  See Â§ 8-13-320(10)(h)
  (â€œThe commission must afford a public official â€¦ who is the subject of a
  complaint the opportunity to be heard on the alleged violation under oath, the
  opportunity to offer information, and the appropriate due process rights,
  including, but not limited to, the right of counsel.â€).Â  Counsel for the
  Commission confirmed at oral argument that the Governor has been allowed to
  offer information during the investigatory process, and has availed himself of
  that opportunity.
[9] It is our opinion the waiver would not apply to the work product of the
  Commission, including mental impressions, generated during the internal
  investigative process.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        In the Matter of FormerNewberry County Associate
          Probate Judge Rebecca A. Allen,         Respondent.
        
      
    
  


Opinion No.Â Â  26738
Submitted October 20, 2009 - Filed November 9, 2009 

PUBLIC REPRIMAND


  
    
      
        Lesley M.
          Coggiola, Disciplinary Counsel, and Joseph P. Turner, Jr., Assistant
          Disciplinary Counsel, both of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary Counsel. 
        Paulette
          Edwards, of Law Office of Paulette Edwards, PA, of Columbia,
          for respondent.Â Â  
      
    
  


PER
  CURIAM:Â  In this judicial disciplinary
  matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered
  into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent (Agreement) pursuant to Rule 21,
  RJDE, Rule 502, SCACR.Â  In the Agreement, respondent admits misconduct and
  consents to the imposition of a public reprimand pursuant to Rule 7(b), RJDE,
  Rule 502, SCACR.[1]Â  The facts as set forth in the Agreement are as follows.Â  
FACTS
\On or between April 19, 2007, and December
  21, 2007, respondent embezzled public funds while working as a Newberry County Associate
  Probate Judge.Â  In mitigation, respondent submits that she took the money to
  pay for medical expenses and to pay deposits needed for surgery and medical
  testing.Â  Further, respondent submits that, at the time she took the money, she
  hoped to repay the funds at a later time. When confronted by agents from the
  South Carolina State Law Enforcement Division (SLED), respondent confessed and
  accepted responsibility for her actions.Â  
On April 28, 2008, respondent was
  arrested and charged with embezzlement of public funds over $1,000.00.Â 
  Respondent entered Pre-Trial Intervention (PTI) and, as a condition of PTI,
  made full restitution.Â  Respondent has successfully completed PTI and her
  criminal record has been expunged.Â  
LAW
By her misconduct, respondent admits she
  has violated the following Canons of the Code of Judicial Conduct, Rule 501,
  SCACR:Â  Canon 1 (judge shall uphold the integrity of the judiciary); Canon 1A
  (judge should participate in establishing, maintaining, and enforcing high
  standards of conduct and shall personally observe those standards so that the
  integrity and independence of the judiciary will be preserved); Canon 2 (judge shall avoid impropriety and the
    appearance of impropriety in all of the judgeâ€™s activities); and Canon 2A (judge shall respect and comply with the law and
      shall act at all times in a manner that promotes public confidence in the
      integrity and impartiality of the judiciary). Â Respondent also admits she has violated Rule
        7(a)(1) (it shall be ground for discipline for judge to violate the Code of
        Judicial Conduct) and Rule 7(a)(9) (it shall be ground for discipline for judge
        to violate the Oath of Office) of the Rules for Judicial Disciplinary
        Enforcement, Rule 502, SCACR.Â  
CONCLUSION 
We accept the Agreement for Discipline by
  Consent and issue a public reprimand.Â  Respondent shall not apply for, seek, or
  accept any judicial position whatsoever in this State without the prior express
  written authorization of this Court after due service
  on ODC of any petition seeking the Courtâ€™s authorization.Â  Respondent is
  hereby reprimanded for her misconduct.Â  
PUBLIC REPRIMAND.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES, BEATTY
  and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.


[1] Respondent no longer holds judicial office.Â  A public
  reprimand is the most severe sanction the Court can impose when a judge no
  longer holds judicial office.Â  See In re Oâ€™Kelley, 361 S.C. 30,
  603 S.E.2d 410 (2004); In re Gravely, 321 S.C. 235, 467 S.E.2d 924
  (1996).

title: Representative Harold Mitchell v. Spartanburg County Legislative Delegation
description: This case was brought under the original jurisdiction of this Court.  In this case, the Court decided that the election of officers to a legislative delegation in South Carolina is a procedural matter such that a simple majority vote is appropriate.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Representative
          Harold Mitchell, Petitioner,
        v.
        Spartanburg
          County Legislative Delegation, Respondent.
      
    
  


ORIGINAL JURISDICTION

Opinion No.Â  26739
  Heard October 6, 2009 - Filed November 9,
2009Â  

JUDGMENT FOR PETITIONER


  
    
      
        Charles
          J. Hodge and T. Ryan Langley, both of Spartanburg, for Petitioner.
        J.
          Derham Cole, Jr., Â of Cole Law Firm, of Spartanburg, Ralph Keith Kelly, of
          Lister Flynn & Kelly, of Spartanburg, Suzanne Boulware Cole, of Collins
          & Lacy, of Greenville,Â  Glenn G. Reese, of Inman,Â  Harvey S. Peeler, Jr.,
          of Gaffney,Â  Joey Millwood, of Landrum,Â  Lee Bright, of Roebuck,Â  Mike Anthony,
          of Union, andÂ  Shane R. Martin, of Pauline, for Respondent.
        Bradley
          S. Wright, Charles F. Reid, Bonnie B. Goldsmith, and Jennifer L. Dobson, all of
          Columbia, for Amicus Curiae, Robert W. Harrell, Jr. Speaker.
        Michael
          R. Hitchcock, S. Phil Lenski, and Kenneth M. Moffitt, all of Columbia, for
          Intervenor, President, Pro Tempore of S. C. Senate. 
      
    
  


CHIEF
  JUSTICE TOAL:Â  Because Harold
  Mitchell's (Petitioner) petition presents an issue of great public interest, we exercise our authority to review this matter in
  our original jurisdiction.Â  S.C. Const. art. V, Â§ 5;
  Rule 245, SCACR; Key v. Currie, 305 S.C. 115, 116, 406 S.E.2d 356, 357
  (1991).Â  
FACTS/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Following the
  November 2008 elections, the Spartanburg County Legislative Delegation
  (Respondent) consisted of thirteen members from the House and Senate.[1]Â 
  On November 10, 2008, Respondent met and elected Rep. Lanny Littlejohn to serve
  as its Chairman by a vote of nine to four and Rep. Keith Kelly to serve as
  Vice-Chairman by a vote of eight to five. Â Subsequent to that meeting, Sen. Lee
  Bright sought an opinion from South Carolina Senate legal counsel regarding the
  procedure Respondent used in selecting officers.Â  That inquiry resulted in a
  letter written to Sen. Bright by Senate staff members John Hazzard and Michael
  Hitchcock that concluded Vander Linden v. Hodges, 193 F.3d 268 (4th Cir.
  1999) requires weighted voting in selecting delegation officers.Â  In response,
  Rep. Keith Kelly sought an opinion from House counsel on the issue.Â  House
  counsel concluded that selection of delegation officers is a matter of internal
  administrative procedure and does not constitute the sort of governmental
  action requiring weighted voting as contemplated by Vander Linden.Â  
The
  members of the delegation split into two factions over whether the officers of
  the delegation should be elected by a simple majority of the delegation or by
  weighted vote according to the number of constituents in each member's
  district.Â  The result of this split was that each group held its own meetings
  as the county delegation. 
Petitioner
  filed a petition on April 4, 2009 seeking the original jurisdiction of this
  Court to resolve this dispute.Â  Subsequent to the filing of the petition to
  this Court, Respondent held a meeting on May 4, 2009.Â  At that meeting, a
  compromise was reached and a vote held whereby the following officers were
  selected: Rep. Lanny Littlejohn as Chairman and Sen. Shane Martin as
  Vice-Chairman.Â  No information was given to the Court about the compromise
  election until briefs were filed in this matter.Â  This Court issued an Order
  dated June 11, 2009 accepting the petition, directing the Petitioner to submit
  a brief, and dispensing with formal requirements of a transcript of record
  given the circumstances of this particular matter.Â Â  
ISSUE
Is
  the election of officers to a legislative delegation in South Carolina a
  procedural matter such that a simple majority vote is appropriate or a
  substantive matter such that a weighted vote is required?
LAW/ANALYSIS
Petitioner
  argues the election of officers to a legislative delegation is a procedural
  matter such that the simple majority method is appropriate.Â  We agree.
In Vander
  Linden, the Fourth Circuit concluded that the Equal Protection Clauseâ€™s one
  person, one vote requirement applied to South Carolina's legislative
  delegations.Â  Vander Linden, 193 F.3d at 281. Â The Fourth Circuit did
  not dictate a remedy, but remanded the case in order to permit the South
  Carolina legislature to correct the constitutional defect.Â  Id.
In determining that
  the one person, one vote rule applied to the election of legislative delegations
  the Fourth Circuit stated, "Focusing on whether the delegations exercise
  governmental functions seems to us entirely appropriate."[2]Â  Id. at 275.Â  "Surely it is fair to infer . . . that the one person,
  one vote rule does not apply to the election of officials who do not 'perform
  governmental functions.'"Â  Id. (emphasis in original). 
Respondent admits
  that the offices of Chairman and Vice-Chairman are ceremonial, pro forma positions.Â  Furthermore, the Chairman and Vice-Chairman: (a) cannot take any
  action on behalf of the delegation save for calling a meeting to order and certain
  other procedural matters, (b) cannot independently exercise any of the substantive
  functions of the delegation except by virtue of their roles as voting members,
  and (c) are not accorded greater weight when voting by virtue of their positions
  as delegation officers.Â  Thus, these officers do not perform substantive duties
  and perform no governmental functions that raise the concerns at issue in Vander
    Linden.Â  Therefore, Vander Linden's weighted voting remedy does not
  apply to the election of Chairman and Vice-Chairman, and these offices can be
  elected by a simple majority vote of the delegation.Â Â 

CONCLUSION
For the
  aforementioned reasons, we find that a simple majority vote is the appropriate
  method of electing county legislative delegation officers.
WALLER,
  PLEICONES, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.


[1] The delegation was comprised of Representatives Rita Allison, Mike Anthony,
  Derham Cole, Jr., Mike Forrester, Keith Kelly, Lanny Littlejohn, Joey Millwood,
  Harold Mitchell, and Steve Parker; Senators Lee Bright, Shane Martin, Harvey
  Peeler, and Glenn Reese.Â  
[2] The governmental functions of the legislative delegation at issue in Vander
  Linden included: (a) making and/or recommending appointments to boards and
  commissions; (b) approving and/or recommending the expenditure of money
  allocated by the South Carolina General Assembly for highways, parks,
  recreation, tourism, and other matters; (c) approving the budgets of local
  school districts; (d) initiating referenda regarding the budgetary powers and
  the election of governing bodies for a special purpose in public service
  districts; (e) approving the reimbursement of expenses for county planning commissioners;
  (f) approving county planning commission contracts with architects, engineers,
  and other consultants; (g) altering or dividing school districts of counties;
  (h) reducing existing special school levies in counties and school districts;
  and (i) submitting grant applications for planning, development, and renovating
  park and recreation facilities.Â  Vander Linden, 193 F.3d at 271.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        
          In the Matter of Kenneth L.
          Mitchum, Respondent.
    
  


Opinion No.Â  26740
Submitted October 13, 2009 - Filed November 9, 2009Â  

INDEFINITE SUSPENSION


  
    
      
        Lesley M.
          Coggiola, Disciplinary Counsel, and Ericka M. Williams, Assistant Disciplinary
          Counsel, both of Columbia, for the Office of Disciplinary Counsel. 
        Kenneth
          L. Mitchum, pro se, of Georgetown.Â  
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this attorney disciplinary matter, respondent and the
  Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered into an Agreement for
  Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  In the
  agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents to any sanction provided
  by Rule 7, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  We accept the agreement and indefinitely
  suspend respondent from the practice of law in this state.Â  The facts, as set
  forth in the agreement, are as follows.Â  
FACTS
I.
Respondent represented
  Complainant A in a civil action.Â  Â Â Respondent failed to keep Complainant A reasonably
  informed regarding the status of the case and failed to diligently pursue the
  case.Â Â  In addition, respondent signed a Stipulation of Dismissal in the case
  without Complainant Aâ€™s knowledge or consent and failed to inform Complainant A
  that he had signed the Stipulation of Dismissal.Â  
II.
Respondent represented a
  client in a civil action.Â  Respondent failed to diligently pursue the case.Â 
  During the representation, respondent was placed on definite suspension for
  nine (9) months and an attorney was appointed to protect the interests of
  respondentâ€™s clients (ATP).Â  In the Matter of Mitchum, 378 S.C. 597, 663
  S.E.2d 482 (2008).Â  
On or about September 26,
  2008, respondent delivered a check to the ATP in the amount of $19,480.00 made
  payable to the client and requested the ATP deliver the check to the client.Â 
  The $19,480.00 check tendered to the client was not the result of any actual
  settlement in the clientâ€™s case.Â  Instead, by tendering the check to the client,
  respondent was attempting to provide financial assistance to the client in
  connection with pending or contemplated litigation.Â Â  
III.
Respondent was retained to
  represent Complainant B in a civil action against a defendant.Â  Respondent was
  served with the defendantâ€™s Interrogatories and Request for Documents; he failed
  to timely respond to either document.Â  Respondent was served with a Notice of
  Motion and a Motion to Compel, but failed to respond to the Motion to Compel.Â 
  Based on respondentâ€™s failure to respond to the Interrogatories, the Request
  for Documents, or the Motion to Compel, Complainant Bâ€™s case was dismissed with
  prejudice. Â Respondent did not notify Complainant B that the matter had been
  dismissed and falsely led Complainant B to believe the case was still on the
  docket for trial.Â  
LAW
Respondent admits that by his
  misconduct he has violated the following provisions of the Rules of
  Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 1.1 (lawyer shall provide
  competent representation); Rule 1.2 (lawyer shall abide by clientâ€™s decision
  whether to accept settlement); Rule 1.3 (lawyer shall act with reasonable
  diligence and promptness in representing clients); Rule 1.4 (lawyer shall keep
  clients informed); Rule 1.8(e) (lawyer shall not provide financial assistance
  to client in connection with pending or contemplated litigation); Rule 3.2 (lawyer shall make reasonable efforts to expedite
  litigation consistent with the interests of the client); Rule 8.4(a) (lawyer shall not violate Rules of Professional
    Conduct); Rule 8.4(e) (lawyer shall not engage in conduct that is prejudicial
    to administration of justice). Â Â In
  addition, respondent admits his misconduct constitutes a violation of Rule 7,
  RLDE, of Rule 413, SCACR, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (lawyer shall not violate
  Rules of Professional Conduct or any other rules of this jurisdiction regarding
  professional conduct of lawyers).[1]Â  
CONCLUSION
We accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and
  indefinitely suspend respondent from the practice of law.Â  Within fifteen days
  of the date of this opinion, respondent shall surrender his certificate of
  admission to practice law in this state to the Clerk of Court and shall file an
  affidavit with the Clerk of Court showing that he has complied with Rule 30,
  RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.
INDEFINITE SUSPENSION.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ.,
  concur.


[1] Respondentâ€™s disciplinary history includes a definite suspension for nine (9)
  months, a definite suspension for ninety (90) days, a public reprimand, a
  private reprimand, and an admonition.Â  In the Matter of Mitchum, 378
  S.C. 597, 663 S.E.2d 482 (2008); In the Matter of Mitchum, 333 S.C.265,
  510 S.E.2d 214 (1998); In the Matter of Mitchum, 331 S.C. 34, 501 S.E.2d
  733 (1998); In the Matter of Two Anonymous Members of the South Carolina Bar,
  278 S.C. 477, 298 S.E.2d 450 (1982).Â Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        
          In the Matter
          of Oliver W. Johnson, III Respondent.
    
  


Opinion No.Â  26742
  Heard September 17, 2009 - Filed November
9, 2009Â  

DISBARRED


  
    
      
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, and Assistant
          Deputy Attorney General J. Emory Smith, Jr., both of Columbia, for Office of
          Disciplinary Counsel.
        Oliver W. Johnson, III, of Columbia, pro se.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM: This disciplinary matter arises out of numerous
  charges filed against Respondent Oliver W. Johnson, III.Â  Following a hearing,
  the Commission on Lawyer Conduct Panel (Panel) recommended that Respondent be
  disbarred.Â  We agree and disbar Respondent effective the date of this opinion.Â  
I.
On September 21, 2000, the
  Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) filed formal charges alleging Respondent
  failed to properly maintain his trust account, misappropriated a portion of a
  $700,000 settlement fund, incurred numerous tax liens and orders related to his
  child support arrearages, failed to represent clients diligently and
  communicate with them, failed to pay a court reporter, an expert witness, and a
  final fee dispute award, and failed to cooperate with ODCâ€™s investigation.Â 
  Subsequently, ODC filed supplemental charges relating to a matter in which
  estate settlement funds were transferred to Respondent to be used for
  litigation purposes, but he failed to properly deliver the funds.Â  Respondent
  filed a response to the initial formal charges, but failed to respond to the
  supplemental charges.Â  
On August 24, 2005, ODC filed
  second supplemental formal charges against Respondent.Â  ODC made further
  allegations regarding the $700,000 settlement fund referenced above,[1] and additionally, alleged Respondent failed to properly disburse funds from a
  conservatorship account, failed to pay an expert witness, and pled guilty to
  assault and battery and willful tax avoidance.Â  Respondent failed to respond to
  these charges.
II.
In November 2006, the Court
  placed Respondent on incapacity inactive status pursuant to Rule 28(b), RLDE,
  Rule 413, SCACR, after he submitted a letter from his doctor stating he was
  treating Respondent for bipolar disorder and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder
  and he felt Respondent was incapable of testifying in a deposition.Â  Respondent
  requested two specific attorneys to be appointed as counsel and as guardian ad
  litem, but both attorneys declined.Â  
On June 1, 2007, a hearing
  was held before the Panel on the issue of Respondentâ€™s incapacity.Â  Respondent
  appeared by telephone, but after he was informed the proceeding would continue
  without the appointment of counsel, he terminated the call.Â  The Panel found
  that Respondent waived his right to present additional medical evidence
  regarding his incapacity and that the letter from his doctor simply stating Respondent
  could not testify was insufficient to show he was unable to assist in his own
  defense.Â  Therefore, the Panel ordered ODC to schedule a final hearing on the
  merits.
Despite receiving notice of
  the merits hearing, Respondent failed to appear.Â  ODC presented testimony from
  four witnesses[2] as well as substantial evidence showing Respondent failed to properly maintain
  his trust, escrow, and operating accounts.Â  The Panel recommended that
  Respondent be disbarred.
Respondent is currently
  incarcerated as a result of federal mortgage fraud charges, which are unrelated
  to this disciplinary matter.Â  After receiving notice that oral arguments before
  this Court were scheduled, Respondent sought a continuance due to his mental
  and physical incapacity and requested that the Court appoint counsel.Â  We
  denied this request.Â  This matter has been pending since 2000.Â  ODC has
  afforded Respondent more than sufficient time to seek counsel as well as
  numerous opportunities to submit any medical records showing he is unable to
  assist in his own defense.Â  Respondent has repeatedly failed to show any
  good-faith or genuine effort in asserting his rights or cooperating with ODC.Â 
  Accordingly, this matter need not be further delayed.
III.
This Court has
  the sole authority to discipline attorneys and to decide the appropriate
  sanction after a thorough review of the record.Â  In re Thompson,
  343 S.C. 1, 10-11, 539 S.E.2d 396, 401 (2000).Â  We â€œmay
  accept, reject, or modify in whole or in part the findings, conclusions and
  recommendations of the [Panel].â€Â  Rule 27(e)(2), RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  Â 
Respondent has engaged in a
  pattern of egregious financial misconduct by misappropriating client funds and
  failing to properly maintain his accounts.Â  This Court â€œhas never regarded financial misconduct lightly, particularly when such
  misconduct concerns expenditure of client funds or other improper use of trust
  funds.â€Â  Matter of McMillan, 327 S.C. 98, 104, 490 S.E.2d 1, 3-4
  (1997).Â  In addition to numerous
  incidents of financial misconduct, Respondent has neglected client matters,
  pled guilty to tax evasion and assault and battery, failed to pay a court
  reporter and expert witness, and failed to cooperate with ODC.Â  Respondentâ€™s
  disciplinary history includes a private reprimand in 1995 and a public
  reprimand in 1998.Â  Matter of Johnson, 329 S.C. 363, 495 S.E.2d
  777 (1998)(imposing a public reprimand
  where Respondent neglected legal matters in two cases and was in arrears on
  child support obligations).Â  In August 1999, this Court placed Respondent on
  interim suspension due to his failure to properly maintain his trust and escrow
  accounts.
By his conduct, we find
  Respondent has violated the following Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407,
  SCACR: 1.1 (lawyer shall provide competent representation); 1.3 (lawyer shall
  act with reasonable diligence and promptness in representing a client);Â  1.4
  (lawyer shall consult and inform client of matters); 1.5 (lawyer shall not
  charge an unreasonable fee); 1.15 (lawyer shall hold property of client or of
  third person separately from his own property); 8.4(a),(b),(d),(e) (lawyer
  shall not: violate the Rules of Professional Conduct; commit a criminal act
  that reflects adversely on the lawyerâ€™s honesty, trustworthiness, or fitness as
  a lawyer; engage in conduct involving dishonesty, fraud, deceit or
  misrepresentation; or engage in conduct that is prejudicial to the
  administration of justice).Â Â Â  
We agree with the Panelâ€™s
  recommendation that Respondent be disbarred from the practice of law.Â  This
  Court has imposed disbarment in similar disciplinary matters.Â  SeeÂ  In
    re Robertson, 383 S.C. 140, 678 S.E.2d 440 (2009) (finding disbarment warranted where attorney failed to disburse
  settlement funds in several cases and neglected his clientsâ€™ cases);Â  In re Tullis, 375 S.C. 190, 652 S.E.2d 395 (2007) (disbarring attorney where attorney failed to adequately communicate with his clients, failed to act with
  diligence and competence, misused and mismanaged trust account funds, and
  failed to respond to ODCâ€™s inquiries); and In
    re Trexler, 343 S.C. 608, 541 S.E.2d 822 (2001) (disbarring attorney for financial misconduct, neglecting client
  matters, and convictions of breach of trust, blackmail, and conspiracy).
Respondent has exhibited a
  pattern of severe, grave, and intentional misconduct without regard for his
  clientsâ€™ interests.Â  Accordingly,
  we disbar Respondent effective the date of this opinion.Â  We further order Respondent to make full
  restitution to all injured parties who have incurred losses as a result of his
  misconduct and order him to pay the costs of these proceedings. Within fifteen
  (15) days of the date of this opinion, Respondent shall file an affidavit with
  the Clerk of Court showing that he has complied with Rule 30, RLDE, Rule 413,
  SCACR, and shall surrender his Certificate of Admission to the Practice of Law
  to the Clerk of Court.
DISBARRED.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER,
  PLEICONES, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

[1]Specifically, ODC alleged that the clientâ€™s signature
  on the settlement statement was forged and Respondent either knew or should
  have known of the forgery.
[2]The four witnesses included: the lawyer who worked
  with Respondent in the estate settlement matter; the court reporter Respondent
  failed to pay; the solicitor who prosecuted Respondentâ€™s client and witnessed
  Respondentâ€™s neglect of his client; and the client involved in the $700,000
  settlement fund.
